indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Oversight committees are functional. 2. Legal research unit established with UNDP support 3. No of priority legislation process supported

baseline.comment: 1. Oversight committees are not functional. 2. No legal research unit exists 3. No legislative priorities developed

actual.comment: 1. Development of a guidance note for Oversight committees on how to conduct public hearings, translated to Somali, approved by Parliament Leadership. 2. Legal Coordination Unit established. 4 Young Graduates, programme funded by UNDP since July 2013, are core part of the staff of the Legal & legislative services department and are receiving specialized training on committee reporting. 3. 4 drafted - Foreign Direct Investment Law; revision of Boundaries and Federation Commission draft law; the Judicial Services Commission Bill.

target.comment: 1. Oversight committees conducting missions. 2. NFP Research office and Library established with UNDP support 3. No. of priority laws of NFP 5th session approved.

actual.comment: 1. Three oversight missions conducted by Somaliland HoR Committees of Discipline, Socials affairs and Public accountss. 2. Library and research office established. Two Trainings delivered to NFP Committee Staff on legislative analysis and drafting. 3. 5 priority legislation review supported. In NFP, support to revision of 3 priority legislation is ongoing: Procurement law, Counter-Terrorism Law and Anti-Money Laundering Law. In Somaliland, 2 legislation supported: the Administrative Law bill, and Budget Act Bill

indicator.description: Annual Board meeting held (Yes/ No). Annual Strategic Review meeting held (Yes/ no). Staff salaries paid.

baseline.comment: Annual Strategic Review meetings held. Annual Project Board meetings held. Police staff in place.

target.comment: 1 Annual Project Board meeting held in each region. 1 Strategic Review meeting held in each region. Project Fully staffed to include: Project Manager, 3 Area Project Managers and National staff working to strengthen the Somali Police in three regions, Federal, Somaliland and Puntland

actual.comment: Annual Project Boards held in Somaliland, Puntland and South Central. Annual Strategic Review meetings held in Somaliland and Puntland. Project fully staffed:1 Project manager; 3 Area Project Managers, 2 National Law Enforcement Experts; 2 Project assistants and one UNV worked as a team within three regions.

indicator.description: % of police female and male officers trained and equipped. Number of police infrastructure constructed and fully operational.

baseline.comment: Police organisation lacking sufficient infrastructure, equipment, training, structure, competencies, oversight and accountability.

target.comment: Develop CID model case file. Support Community Police Unit for better community access to police. Provide Armo academy trainers assessment and TOT training. Procure and deliver 9 police vehicles and required essential police tools. Construct 6 Model Police stations and provide equipment.

actual.comment: 3 Model Police Stations and 1 CID office constructed, equipped and fully operational. 209/38F of Puntland Police staff received basic and advanced trainings on crime reporting & statistics, TOT programmes, SGBV CID basic and advanced, Protocol and weapon management and use of force.1846 items in total have been handed over to the counterpart. This includes Furniture 264 items, IC equipment 75 items, Radio and Communication equipment 90 items, Forensics tools 200 items, Solar panels 8, Motor transport 9 police pick up, Police register books and guidance booklets 1200 copies.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 2.4.2.1 Number of legal professionals that have received training on sexual and gender-based violence 2.4.2.2 Number of citizens receiving legal aid, disaggregated by gender 2.4.2.3 Number of legal aid centres supported 2.4.2.4 Number of cases fully adjudicated in court, disaggregated by criminal and civil cases 2.4.2.5 Number of rape and SGBV cases, disaggregated by dismissals and convictions 2.4.3.1 Level of sample judicial written decisions justifying outcomes based on legal reasoning in accordance with international and national rights frameworks, and other constitutional and legal reforms is high, medium , or low

baseline.comment: Weak Legal System that has no presence outside the major cities

target.comment: 170 scholarships supported.(all regions of Somalia) 11,300 clients receive legal aid.(all regions of Somalia) 2,100 cases heard by mobile courts.(all regions of Somalia) Case management system expanded to additional regions. training activities for judges and lawyers. Policy and legal drafting unit established. Legal drafting manual developed and staff trained on its use. Legal Aid policy disseminated. Puntland Rule of Law Needs Assessment completed. Gardo prison completed.

actual.comment: 239 public servants (F:60, M:179) received organized trainings. Out of these 25 (F:4, M:21) were Court Registrars from across Puntland trained on Case Management and the Puntland Civil and Criminal Procedure codes; 35 ( F:2, M:33) were Mobile Court Teams trained on SGBV, human rights, Puntland Family Law Act 2013 and mediation skills. 179 (F:54, M:125) were trained on the Puntland Legal Aid Policy 51 (F:7, M:44) received training on sexual and gender-based violence. Out of the 51 were 35 (F:2, M:33) members of Mobile Court Teams including Judges and court registrars. 16 (F:5, M:11) were PLAC lawyers and paralegals. 63 (F:24, M:39) scholarships were provided for the academic year that ended in October 2014. 45 students were in their second year of study while 18 were in the fourth year and are expected to graduate in early 2015. 18 (F:7, M:11) graduate interns were supported in justice sector institutions 5 Puntland Legal Aid Centres supported with 9 (F:2, M:7) lawyers, 39 (F:16, M:23) paralegals and 7 (F:4, M:3)interns. 2996 (F:1951, M:1045) people received legal aid. 1521 (F:905, M:616) provided with legal representation from lawyers and 1475 (F:1046, M:429) from paralegals. Of the 1521 cases dealt with by lawyers 772 (F:447, M:325) were resolved, 17 (F:4, M:13) dismissed and 444 (F:243, M:201) are pending. Of the 1475 cases dealt with by paralegals through mediation out of which 1369 (F:845, M:494) were resolved. Of the 2996 people who received legal aid 2608 were IDPs. 461 of the cases related to SGBV. 1285 people (F:773, M:512) were reached through legal awareness sessions 331 out of 390 cases resolved in favour of women in securing women's economic rights 461 SGBV cases were reported to UNDP supported legal aid providers. 349 of these were provided with legal representation with 7 convictions, 153 pending, and 113 were referred to other institutions, dropped, mediated or survivors provided with psychosocial support. Training on the use of the case management

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 2.4.2.1 Number of legal professionals that have received training on sexual and gender-based violence 2.4.2.2 Number of citizens receiving legal aid, disaggregated by gender 2.4.2.3 Number of legal aid centres supported 2.4.2.4 Number of cases fully adjudicated in court, disaggregated by criminal and civil cases 2.4.2.5 Number of rape and SGBV cases, disaggregated by dismissals and convictions 2.4.3.1 Level of sample judicial written decisions justifying outcomes based on legal reasoning in accordance with international and national rights frameworks, and other constitutional and legal reforms is high, medium , or low

baseline.comment: Judicial staff are too few, especially women and are lacking in qualification. Somalis, especially women, remain unequal before the law. Legal traininng, including judge's training, is available throughout Somalia. Bar associations are in place in SOuth Central, Somaliland and Puntland. No UNDP supported legal clinics in South Central, but legal aid centres run by NGOs exist in some cases. 1 legal clinic in Somaliland and 1 legal aid centre in Puntland. Poor awareness of human rights and mechanisms for redress.

target.comment: 170 scholarships supported. 11,300 clients receive legal aid. training activities for judges and lawyers. Benadir Court rehabilitated and security improved. Draft legislation and legal policies are approved by Minister and sent to Cabinet for approval.

actual.comment: 166 (F:22, M:144). 31 MOJ and Judiciary staff benefited from organized trainings on Legal Drafting and Participatory Policy Development, Justice Sector Reform Strategies and Project Cycle Management, with also 14 of the 31 were further trained on the functioning of Joint Implementation Units. 47 (F:23, M:24) scholarships were provided for the academic year ending October 2014. 13 (F:6, M:7) graduate interns were supported in justice sector institutions 3 legal aid offices in Mogadishu supported with 11 (F:6, M:5) lawyers, 51 (F:43, M:8) paralegals and 20 (F:10, M:10) interns 3027 (F:1192, M:1835) received legal aid. 1770 (F:277, M11493) from lawyers and 1257 (F:915, M:342) from paralegals. Of the 1770 cases dealt with by lawyers 1200 (F:193, M:1007) were resolved, 457 (F:50, M:407) pending and 113 (F:34, M:79) dismissed. Of the 3027 people receiving legal aid 1709 clients were IDPs. 435 of the cases dealt with related to SGBV. 8792 (F:7683, M:1109) people participated in legal awareness sessions 435 SGBV cases reported to 3 legal aid partners of which 147 were taken to court (39 accused were convicted, 64 had their charges dropped and 44 are still pending). The remaining 288 survivors were provided psychosocial support and counseling 12 out of the 16 districts of the Mogadishu have functional district courts. However, 7 of these work outside their home districts for security reasons. They are temporarily based at the Benadir Court Complex. Judicial Services Commission Act was adopted on 30 June. This is a milestone in establishing mechanisms for vetting, licensing and appointing judicial personnel and ensuring accountability and oversight in the justice sector. 10 Laws drafted, reviewed and pubic consultations by the project supported Policy and Legal Drafting Unit (PLDU) of Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs. Of this 1 Law (Judicial Service Commission) enacted by Parliament but not yet implemented by the executive Other 9 Laws / Acts: Judicial Organizat

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Benadir Court refurbished and operating. Case management system established. Judicial Services Commission established. Number of legal professionals that received training. Number of citizens receiving legal aid. Number of cases fully adjudicated in court.

baseline.comment: Benadir Court partially destroyed. No case management system in existence. 20 legal practitioners received basic training. No support to Judiciary Services Council.

target.comment: Introduce Case Management in Mogadishu. Rehabilitation of the Benadir Court Complex. Legal Aid (defence) Legislative reform including review of the criminal procedure code as well as the penal code and translation into Somali;

actual.comment:
The Policy and legal drafting unit was established in the Ministry of Justice and it undertook drafting, reviews and or public consultations on ten key priority laws, importantly including the Judicial Service Commission Act.
Judicial Service Commission Act passed by Parliament on 30 June 2014 and the Judicial Service Commission was established in July 2014, which has the responsibility and leadership for the implementation of judicial training.
The Judicial Services Commission Act now providing mechanism for vetting, licensing and appointing judicial personnel and ensuring accountability and oversight in the justice sector.
Attorney General Office was established in the Benadir Court Complex and technical operational support was provided to the office Detailed site security survey and assessment and engineering assessment completed for Benadir Court Complex. Civil works for rehabilitation and security enhancement for Benadir Court Complex commenced and 22% of the work has been completed, with the rest estimated to finish in May 2015.
Ten day training on judicial protection and security was conducted for 75 personnel of Benadir Court Complex team. Security equipment was also purchased for security staff at the Benadir Court Complex and training conducted on their use.
3 legal aid offices were supported in Mogadishu.
50 (F:25, M:25) legal professionals receive legal training at Mogadishu university through scholarships.

target.comment: Enhance capacity of JSC through training programmes, including training on piracy matters Conduct training of justice sector personnel, with focus on matters related to piracy cases

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Community economic needs are identified - Community economic needs are addressed through community development plans - Number of basic services and economic infrastructure rehabilitated, functioning and effectively sustained, disaggregated by type - Number of skilled and unskilled workers provided with short term employment - Number of medium to long term jobs created

baseline.comment: - Low appreciation and understanding of local community potentials and capabilities by other stakeholders from outside the communities - Government finance and services delivery system are very limited and weak - Low participation of local communities in water resource management, advance recovery environment, conflict and crises management - Low sustainability of interventions - Interventions are not responsive to the actual priorities and needs - Poor services and infrastructure - Limited job opportunities

target.comment: 1. Need assessment to identify the economic recovery needs and integration means of refugees/ returnees/ IDPs in Kismayo, Luuq and Baidoa 2. Establish a business services center in Hargeisa to provide referrals, advisory support and training to micro-entrepreneurs especially women 3. Economic Integration and support livelihoods of undetermined number of Refugees/ IDPs/ returnees in Baidoa, Luuq and Kismayo 4. One road of 2.2 km long will be rehabilitated in Hafun and Gabions to protect a road will be constructed in Bandr Bayle 5. 4 basic infrastructure facilities including schools, roads, markets, health and centers will rehabilitated in Mogadishu and Baidoa 6. Road rehabilitation in Berbera district 7. 11 berkades in Burao and Odwayne districts 8. Introduce flood protection intervention in Burao area 9. Upgrading of Burao Technical institute (second phase) 10. Improve the fishing gear of the fisheries in Berbera 11. Introduce appropriate technology schemes related to irrigation, roads construction and renewable energy 12. Rehabilitation of 2 basic social infrastructure (schools, MCHs, market) in Bari and Togdheer regions\ 13. Puntland: Through rehabilitation of the road in Hafun and the gabions in B/ Bayle, at least 650 short term job opportunity for 196 women and 454 men for a period of 30 days will be created 14. Somaliland: Through rehabilitation of 8 basic infrastructure mentioned in output one, at least 1000 job opportunities (30% women) for a period of 30 days will be created 15. Federal Regions: 16. a. Through rehabilitation of 8 basic infrastructure mentioned in output one, at least 1200 job opportunities (30% women) for a period of 30 days will be created 17. Economic empowerment of 460 youth and women in Eyl, Bander Bayle and Graad through social rehabilitation programme, skills training and provision of micro grants and start-up tools 18. Somaliland: Through rehabilitation of productive infrastructure including fishing gears and wat

actual.comment: 1. Need assessment to identify the economic recovery needs and integration means of refugees/ returnees/ IDPs in Kismayo, Luuq and Baidoa 2. Undertake a feasibility study to establish a business services center in Hargeisa to provide referrals, advisory support and training to micro-entrepreneurs especially women 3. One road of 2.2 km long e rehabilitated in Hafun and Gabions to protect a road constructed in Bandr Bayle 4. 2 basic infrastructure facilities including schools, roads, markets, health and centers rehabilitated in Mogadishu and Baidoa 5. Road rehabilitation in Berbera district 6. 11 berkades in Burao and Odwayne districts 7. Introduce flood protection intervention in Burao area 8. Puntland: Through rehabilitation of the road in Hafun and the gabions in B/ Bayle, at least 650 short term job opportunity for 196 women and 454 men for a period of 30 days created 9. Somaliland: Through rehabilitation of basic infrastructure mentioned in output one, at least 350 job opportunities (30% women) for a period of 30 days created 10. Economic empowerment of 460 youth and women in Eyl, Bander Bayle and Graad through social rehabilitation programme, skills training and provision of micro grants and start-up tools 11. Through rehabilitation of productive infrastructure including fishing gears and water resources, at least 300 people will sustain their income

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

baseline.comment: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.

target.comment: Not Applicable

actual.comment: Not Applicable

target.comment: A Land Use Policy in each zone (Somaliland, Puntland and South Central) is initiated

actual.comment: 0 Concept notes prepared by the relevant government institutions in Puntland and Somaliland were approved and implementation of activities commenced to develop land use policies. South-Central regions to be covered through the Federal government in third quarter of 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Output 1: - # of reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS - IRAs charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process - % of Women participating in reconciliation process/forums Output 2: Boundaries & Federation Commission (BFC) formation act is endorsed in parliament - % of women in BFC - % of members receive office equipment and tools to work - Refurbish and provide office equipment and tools for BFC office operation and support - Number of BFC members trained on framework and policy on Boundary and Federalism process. Output 3: - % of IRAs target population receive good governance and federalism messages - # of workshop/seminars/conferences conducted. Output 4: # of TA provided to MOIFA - % of Federal directorate receive office equipment support - # of MOIFA staff receive basic training to support federalism - # of Federal- interim consultative meets organized Output 5: % of Interim Regional Administration(IRA) receiving capacity building support - % of IRA staff trained in core functions area on basic service delivery process

target.comment:
Output 1: - At least two Reconciliation Conferences conducted towards state building process - Charters Drafted for each IRAs Output 2: - BFC is established based on FGS provisional constitution. - 20% women are members in BFC - 90% of BFC members receive required office equipment and tools to function Output 3: -In all IRAs good governance and federalism messages are broadcasted - At least two workshops/conferences are conducted. - One Regional development plan per IRA is developed. Output 4: - At least 35 MOIFA staff trained on governance and federalism - At least 6 consultative Meetings organized inclusive of PSG1 in regions - 70% of Federal directorate receive office equipment support
Output 5: - All four IRAs receive capacity building support. - 70% of IRA officials trained in basic management functions - Selected IRAs offices are rehabilitated

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Output 1: 1.1: Political and civil agreement on the establishment of the state government structures (Legitimacy: draft charters and similar). 1.2: % representation of women, youth and marginalized groups in the reconciliation efforts Output 2: 2.1 # of TC secretariat established 2.2. # of public awareness and promotional material developed with specific attention to dedicated audiences including women, youth and marginalized groups. 2.3. # IRAs formed and structures are in place: endorsed charters, institutional establishment decrees, legal documents, etc.) Output 3: 1 Number of bills/laws passed in the parliament 2. % Commissioners BFC are in place and % of them receive office equipments Output 4: # of technical advisors and # of young graduates hired and are actively supporting the state formation and reconciliation Output 5: 1. Medium term project developed through consultative process

baseline.comment: Output 1: While there is large political will, also diverging opinions exist and broad- based political and civil agreements have not yet been fully realized Output 2. 18 members Technical Committee established in both Baidoa and Central regions, but not endowed with a Secretariat. Output 3. Establishment act for the Boundary and Federalism Commission drafted and tabled for Parliaments review and approval Output 4: Department specifically in charge of Federal Affairs exist within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity. And Interim administration does not exist Output 5: 1. Short term or adhoc support available to the emerging states

target.comment: Target: Output 1: 1.1: At least two Regional reconciliation/civil agreement established to initiate formation of interim administrations 2. 1.2: 15% of representatives of women /youth and marginalized groups are in reconciliation process Output 2: 2.1. At least two interim administrations established and State legislative members in place. 2.2. At least one national level public outreach campaign initiated. 2.3. Formal establishment arrangements of the state government structures (Legality: endorsed charters, institutional establishment decrees, legal documents, etc.) Output 3: 1 BFC Law is endorsed by the Cabinet , FGS 2. 100% of BFC members/commissioners are in place and at least 40% of them receive office equipment Output 4: Atleast two technical advisors and 10 young graduates are hired to support Directorate of Federal affairs to facilitate and oordinate interim administration Output 5: Fully fledge Project document developed by end of April 2015 to support interim administration

indicator.title: Output Indicator

actual.comment: 1. Three oversight missions conducted by Somaliland HoR Committees of Discipline, Socials affairs and Public accountss. Regional authorities and services contacted to investigate on security situation (Togdheer Region), enquire on provison of health and education services (Awadal), and the level of transparency and accountability at customs and revenue collection points to investigate (Awadal and Sanaag regions). 2. 640 MPs and their staff trained on developing agenda, parliamentary functions, orders of business etc. 3. A workshop on communication and outreach skills of MPs and constituency office staff 25 (M: 24 F: 1) conducted in Hargeisa. Using the skills gained during the first two days of the workshop, participants developed individual outreach action plans for each constituency office.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Establishment of NIEC as a credible and capable government institution able to plan and conduct electoral operations in Somalia 2. The legal framework for electoral processes is in place 3. A 2016 electoral process (Parliament renewal) is developed and implemented 4. A coordination mechanism is in place between Government, UN, donors and electoral assistance providers to focused, effective and coherent international electoral assistance delivery

baseline.comment: 1. No recent history of national electoral processes in the Federal Republic of Somalia (no NIEC) 2. No legal framework in place for elections 3. Political ambiguity regarding upcoming national electoral processes (2016-2020). 4. A number of international electoral assistance providers are currently supporting the Federal government of Somalia and improved coordination is required

target.comment: 1. Appointment of NIEC Commissioners, physical establishment in place, institutional capacity development started 2. NIEC Law is passed 3. National Consultative Process is launched 4. Systematic coordination between electoral partners and stakeholders (Gov, donors, UN, electoral assistance providers)

actual.comment: 1. NIEC Commissioners have been appointed in July 2015. Through UNDP support, (temporary) offices have been established and equipment provided; capacity development efforts initiated (strategic planning, organizational development, electoral knowledge building). (NIEC Institutional Planning Workshops in Aug and October, BRIDGE training provided to MOIFA officials in August). 2. The NIEC Law has been passed by Parliament in February 2015. 3. On 19-21 September 2015, the National Consultative Process was launched. The first meeting of the Consultative Forum takes place on 14 October. 4. PSG1 (sub)working meeting held on 9-10 September with partners on coordination of electoral processes in 2016; Project Board Meeting on 10 September; NIEC Coordination meeting on 2 October

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of regions that adopt quota system for women 2. Number of women that contest in national elections supported by UNDP. 3. Number of electoral policies that mainstream gender equality

baseline.comment: 1. No quotas for women in all 3 regions. 2. Data on women candidates for electoral offices at national level not available 3. No gender mainstreamed electoral policies

target.comment: Not applicable

actual.comment: Not applicable

target.comment: At least 5 media stories on women in the private sector 10 private sector companies advocated adopting gender-sensitive policies and recruiting women.

actual.comment:
The media training on Gender was held in Uganda from 14th to 17th September.The media training on gender aims to equip key leaders of media industry ( journalists, reporters and media owners) in different regions, 11 from Federal Government, 15 from Puntland and 3 from Somaliland to a better understanding of gender equality issues in media reporting and strengthen their ability to investigate and develop reports and stories on gender and womens issues Somali Women entrepreneurs were supported to participate in the Somali Investment Forum in Nairobi from the 8th to 10th March 2015. The event brought together Somali entrepreneurs, investors, sector experts, business development experts and other stakeholders all of whom are focused on Somalia to discuss Somali investing and seeks to catalyze business growth by bringing Diaspora investor and entrepreneurs and other stakeholders together to engage in a series of practical call to action events. There has been specific session on Women Entrepreneurs structured along the study on the role of women in the private sector recommendations commissioned by UNDP in 2014. UNDP GEWE has been privileged to present the findings of the private sector study. Gender project conducted meetings with 30 women from CSOs to explore the best strategies of promoting gender parity in the Somalia CO and recommended to reconvene after 6 months to measure the progressive of gender parity in Somalia and how the insights of these meetings are being applied by UNDP in order to ensure 50/50 gender parity in its staff. The follow up meeting will be held in Q3 to review the progressive change of gender parity in UNDP staff. In Puntland and Somaliland, the project continued to support young women tertiary scholarship recipients (30 in PL and 29 SL). Tuition fees, transportation and text book allowances were provided to the students to peruse the first semester of their third academic year.
At federal level, the Ministry of Education was enga
